The primary objective of this study was to examine how various types of initial conditions influence the development of density perturbations within an expanding universe characterized by a positive cosmological constant (dark energy).

We employed two approaches to numerically solve the Einstein equations in conjunction with the matter fields: the traditional method that expands the metric tensor using spherical harmonics, and the novel method we developed that utilizes Chebyshev polynomial expansion of the metric.

In both scenarios, we examine three types of initial conditions: Gaussian random fields produced through the Zel'dovich approximation, Gaussian random fields generated by a fast Fourier transform algorithm, and white noise.
Our findings indicate that all of these models produce comparable predictions at later times when extended to z = 0.5.
However, there are certain differences between them in their early stages.

These differences can be explained in the following way: the Zel'dovich model anticipates larger fluctuations than other models, primarily because it neglects the pressure term in the fluid equation. In contrast, the white noise model results in smaller fluctuations due to its inherent statistical characteristics. Lastly, the Gaussian random fields generated through the fast Fourier transform algorithm yield intermediate fluctuation values.

This finding indicates that the selection of initial conditions can have a considerable impact on the final value of the power spectrum of primordial density fluctuations as predicted by inflationary theories.

We introduce innovative techniques for measuring the mass-loss rate in evolved stars (AGB) through radio observations at centimeter wavelengths, and we contrast these findings with those derived from infrared dust emission measurements.
We analyze archival VLA data from three nearby carbon-rich AGB stars: IK Tau, IRC+10216, and AFGL 3068, all of which are recognized for their significant mass-loss rates.
The measured flux densities are compared to the predictions generated by spherically symmetric radiative transfer models, which take into account both free-free and thermal dust emission components.
For every star, we observe a strong correlation between our model predictions and the measured flux density values, provided we use a suitable mass-loss rate.
Our findings indicate that mass-loss rates obtained from radio continuum observations can serve as dependable estimates of the total mass lost in the late stages of stellar evolution.
These findings illustrate the significant role that radio observations play in placing essential constraints on theoretical models of circumstellar envelopes surrounding evolved stars.
We present our findings on the observation of electronic spin transport over large distances (several millimeters) in suspended single-layer graphene devices at room temperature.

The experiments involved nonlocal spin-valve measurements utilizing ferromagnetic contacts, which were created by sputtering Co/Ni multilayers onto exfoliated graphite flakes, and subsequently annealing them to produce cobalt silicide contacts.

We note that the resistance-area product (RA) is heavily influenced by the geometry of the contacts. Specifically, our findings indicate that RA experiences a substantial decrease when the length of one contact exceeds 1 micron.
This behavior can be understood by examining the impact of disorder scattering occurring at the interface between the metal and the carbon atoms.
Furthermore, we demonstrate that the strength of the spin signal is highly sensitive to the relative alignment of the magnetization directions in the two ferromagnets.

These findings indicate that the detected spin signals are mainly the result of spin injection into the graphene layer, rather than being primarily influenced by proximity effects or other mechanisms related to the magnetic contacts.

We showcase new near-infrared (NIR) polarimetric observations of the GG Tau system, highlighting the intricate structure of its circumstellar disk, which features multiple bright areas exhibiting varying polarization characteristics.
The most notable characteristic of our data set is an arc-shaped structure situated approximately 0.5 arcseconds to the southeast of the central binary star.
This region exhibits significant polarized emission, reaching up to 10% of the total intensity, and was previously recognized as a reflection nebula by Weintraub et al. (1993).
We determine that this characteristic can be attributed to scattering from optically thin dust particles situated near the midplane of the disk.
Through addition, we identify two additional bright features on both sides of the central binary.
These also exhibited significant levels of linear polarization, yet there is no definitive indication of scattered light.
Instead, they seem to result from absorption against the backdrop of stellar radiation.
In addition, we discover three more faint structures located in the southern region of the disk.
All these features exhibit similar polarization angles, suggesting that their origins could be interconnected.
We present five newly discovered planets identified by the NASA K2 mission, which were detected among the targets observed during Campaigns 1 and 2 (C1/K2).
The potential planets are all situated within 100 parsecs of Earth, with orbital periods varying from 3 days to 16 years.
We showcase the light curves from their discovery, along with follow-up photometric data collected from various observatories across the globe.
All five objects have been verified as planetary-mass companions through radial velocity measurements obtained via high-resolution spectroscopy or precise astrometry.

Keywords: Planetary systems - Discovery methods - Radial velocities - Astrometry - Transits - Exoplanet - K2 Mission - Nearby stars - TESS - PLATO - HARPS-N - SPECULOOS

Unfortunately, technical challenges limited continuous observation to only about one third of the initial target list during this period.

In this study, we present the discovery of five new planets identified by K2, which were detected within the targets observed during campaigns 1 and 2 (C1/K2).

We present an enhanced measurement of the abundance in the black hole binary nova Sco X-1, utilizing high-resolution optical spectroscopy collected with UVES at VLT-UT2 during November 2004 and January 2005.
The newly gathered data was merged with existing published findings to determine the abundances of CNO elements, along with Fe I and Fe II lines.
Our best-fit model aligns well with previous studies when considering their uncertainties.
Nonetheless, our findings reveal substantially reduced values for carbon and oxygen compared to those reported by Gies & Bolton (1986).
This inconsistency could be attributed to variations in the atmospheric models or atomic data employed in the two analyses.

Keywords: Black holes, abundance ratios, X-ray binaries, spectroscopy, ultraviolet space observatories, variability, velocity fields, stellar winds, mass transfer, X-ray emission, accretion disks, novae, supernovae.

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) hold great potential for field emission devices thanks to their distinctive physical and chemical characteristics, including a high aspect ratio, low work function, and remarkable mechanical strength.
In this research, we introduce a comprehensive multiphysics model designed to simulate the system response of carbon nanotube (CNT) based field emitting diodes (FEDs).
The proposed model comprises three sub-models: 1) electron transport within carbon nanotubes (CNT); 2) the distribution of electrostatic potential; and 3) the distribution of current density.
We created these models utilizing the COMSOL Multiphysics software suite, which features integrated physics modules.

To validate our simulation results, we constructed a CNT-FED device by growing vertically aligned carbon nanotubes on a silicon substrate using the plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition method, followed by sputtering a gold film on top.
Our experimental findings align well with the simulated results generated by the proposed model.
